question: Do you understand the enterprise-wide risk appetite for your applications ?
comments: We inform the risks above certain level. We propose mitigations. If risk is left uncovered, we have no idea which criteria are used for approving or vetting new releases.

question: Do you have a strategic plan for application security and use it to make decisions?
answer: Yes, we consult the plan often, and it is aligned with our application security strategy
comments: As a developer there are clear guidelines on what we should do regarding security. The plan is consistent to what we hear from above our level, but we don’t know about the details of what actually happens in the upper levels of the company

question: Do you regularly review and update the Strategic Plan for Application Security?
comments: It is not up to developers to do a review of the plan. We can propose small changes to the processes regarding security in the application, but general guidelines are enforced from above our level in the organization.

question: Do you use a set of metrics to measure the effectiveness and efficiency of the application security program across applications?
comments: I am not aware of any metrics regarding effectiveness or efficiency.

question: Did you define Key Perfomance Indicators (KPI) from available application security metrics?
comments: I am not aware of any KPIs.

question: Do you update the Application Security strategy and roadmap based on application security metrics and KPIs?
comments: I am not aware of any KPIs.

question: Do you have and apply a common set of policies and standards throughout your organization?
comments: For COMPANY part of the application, everything is the same. For other parts of COMPANY I know that there is the Security Reliability Model that tries to standardize security related things throughout the organization, but I don’t know about the specifics in other departments at COMPANY.

question: Do you publish the organization's policies as test scripts or run-books for easy interpretation by development teams?
Do you regularly report on policy and standard compliance, and use that information to guide compliance improvement efforts?
Do you have a complete picture of your external compliance obligations?
comments: No, but I guess the Security Reliability Model takes care of it.

question: Do you have a standard set of security requirements and verification procedures addressing the organization's external compliance obligations?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the obligations
comments: I guess the Security Reliability Model takes care of it.

question: Do you regularly report on adherence to external compliance obligations and use that information to guide efforts to close compliance gaps?
Do you require employees involved with application development to take SDLC training?
comments: Owasp top 10 yes, for almost everyone. People who join get the same training. I don’t know about Defense in Depth, Fail Secure, Complete Mediation, etc.

question: Is training customized for individual roles such as developers, testers, or security champions?
comments: As a developer and security master, I got more or less the same training

question: Have you implemented a Learning Management System or equivalent to track employee training and certification processes?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the training

question: Have you identified a Security Champion for each development team?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the teams

question: Does the organization have a Secure Software Center of Excellence (SSCE)?
comments: Yes, as part of the Security Reliability Model.

question: Is there a centralized portal where developers and application security professionals from different teams and business units are able to communicate and share information?
comments: Yes, as part of the Security Reliability Model.

question: Do you classify applications according to business risk based on a simple and predefined set of questions?
answer: Yes, most or all of them

question: Do you use centralized and quantified application risk profiles to evaluate business risk?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the applications

question: Do you regularly review and update the risk profiles for your applications?
Do you identify and manage architectural design flaws with threat modeling?
Do you use a standard methodology, aligned on your application risk levels?
Do you regularly review and update the threat modeling methodology for your applications?
Do project teams specify security requirements during development?
Do you define, structure, and include prioritization in the artifacts of the security requirements gathering process?
Do you use a standard requirements framework to streamline the elicitation of security requirements?
Do stakeholders review vendor collaborations for security requirements and methodology?
Do vendors meet the security responsibilities and quality measures of service level agreements defined by the organization?
Are vendors aligned with standard security controls and software development tools and processes that the organization utilizes?
Do teams use security principles during design?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the applications

question: Do you use shared security services during design?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the applications

question: Do you base your design on available reference architectures?
Do you evaluate the security quality of important technologies used for development?
Do you have a list of recommended technologies for the organization?
Do you enforce the use of recommended technologies within the organization?
Is your full build process formally described?
Is the build process fully automated?
Do you enforce automated security checks in your build processes?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the applications

question: Do you have solid knowledge about dependencies you're relying on?
Do you handle 3rd party dependency risk by a formal process?
Do you prevent build of software if it's affected by vulnerabilities in dependencies?
Do you use repeatable deployment processes?
Are deployment processes automated and employing security checks?
Do you consistently validate the integrity of deployed artifacts?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the applications

question: Do you limit access to application secrets according to the least privilege principle?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the applications

question: Do you inject production secrets into configuration files during deployment?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the applications

question: Do you practice proper lifecycle management for application secrets?
Do you track all known security defects in accessible locations?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the applications

question: Do you keep an overview of the state of security defects across the organization?
Do you enforce SLAs for fixing security defects?
Do you use basic metrics about recorded security defects to carry out quick win improvement activities?
Do you improve your security assurance program upon standardized metrics?
Do you regularly evaluate the effectiveness of your security metrics so that its input helps drive your security strategy?
Do you review the application architecture for key security objectives on an ad-hoc basis?
Do you regularly review the security mechanisms of your architecture?
Do you regularly review the effectiveness of the security controls?
Do you review the application architecture for mitigations of typical threats on an ad-hoc basis?
Do you regularly evaluate the threats to your architecture?
Do you regularly update your reference architectures based on architecture assessment findings?
Do you test applications for the correct functioning of standard security controls?
answer: Yes, most or all of them

question: Do you consistently write and execute test scripts to verify the functionality of security requirements?
answer: Yes, most or all of them

question: Do you automatically test applications for security regressions?
Do you test applications using randomization or fuzzing techniques?
Do you create abuse cases from functional requirements and use them to drive security tests?
Do you perform denial of service and security stress testing?
comments: I know that there is measurement about how many TPS a node can take

question: Do you scan applications with automated security testing tools?
answer: Yes, most or all of them

question: Do you customize the automated security tools to your applications and technology stacks?
Do you integrate automated security testing into the build and deploy process?
Do you manually review the security quality of selected high-risk components?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the components

question: Do you perform penetration testing for your applications at regular intervals?
Do you use the results of security testing to improve the development lifecycle?
answer: Yes, but we improve it ad-hoc

question: Do you analyze log data for security incidents periodically?
Do you follow a documented process for incident detection?
Do you review and update the incident detection process regularly?
Do you respond to detected incidents?
Do you use a repeatable process for incident handling?
Do you have a dedicated incident response team available?
Do you harden configurations for key components of your technology stacks?
Do you have hardening baselines for your components?
Do you monitor and enforce conformity with hardening baselines?
Do you identify and patch vulnerable components?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the components

question: Do you follow an established process for updating components of your technology stacks?
Do you regularly evaluate components and review patch level status?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the components

question: Do you protect and handle information according to protection requirements for data stored and processed on each application?
answer: Yes, for most or all of the applications

question: Do you maintain a data catalog, including types, sensitivity levels, and processing and storage locations?
Do you regularly review and update the data catalog and your data protection policies and procedures?
Do you identify and remove systems, applications, application dependencies, or services that are no longer used, have reached end of life, or are no longer actively developed or supported?
Do you follow an established process for removing all associated resources, as part of decommissioning of unused systems, applications, application dependencies, or services?
Do you regularly evaluate the lifecycle state and support status of every software asset and underlying infrastructure component, and estimate their end of life?
